sp.p: returning and looking anxiously after Bronzely. I am passionate—I am precipitate—I have no command over my temper.—However, if a man cannot govern himself, yet he will never make any very despicable figure, as long as he knows how to govern his wife. Exit.

head.stage: Sir William's Apartment at Mr. Norberry's.—Several trunks and travelling boxes.—Sir William discovered, packing writings into a port-folio.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And here is the end of my voyage to England!—a voyage, which, for years, my mind has dwelt on with delight!—I pictured to myself my daughter grown to womanhood, beautiful! and so she is.—Accomplished! and so she is.—Virtuous! and so she is.—Am I of a discontented nature then, that I am not satisfied?—Am I too nice?—Perhaps I am.—Soothing thought!—I will for a moment cherish it, and dwell with some little gratitude upon her late anxiety for my safety. He walks about in a thoughtful musing manner.

div3.stage: A loud thrusting and rapping is heard at his chamber door.
Enter Miss Dorrillon hastily and in affright.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Mandred, I beg your pardon—I did not know this was your apartment. But suffer me to lock the door: she locks it and conceal me for a moment, for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What's the matter? Why have you locked my door?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: trembling. I dare not tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I insist upon knowing.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Why then—I am pursued by a——I cannot name the horrid name—

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: Without. She went into this room.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: to Sir William. Go to the door, and say I did not.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: without Please to open the door.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Threaten to beat him if he won't go away.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Give me the key, and let me see from whom you want to hide.— commandingly—Give me the key.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: collecting firmness. I will not.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: starting."Will not"—"Will not," when I desire you!

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: No—since you refuse me protection, I'll protect myself.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But you had better not have made use of that expression to me—you had better not. Recall it by giving me the key.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: If I do, will you let me conceal myself behind that book-case, and say I am not here?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Utter a falsehood?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: I would for you. A hammering at the door.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: They are breaking open the door.—Give me the key, I command you.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: "Command me!" "command me!" However, there it is. Gives it him. And now, if you are a gentleman, give me up if you dare!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: "If I am a gentleman!" Hem, hem—"if I am a gentleman!" "Dares" me too!

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Yes. I have now thrown myself upon your protection; and if you deliver me to my enemies—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What enemies? What business have you with enemies?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis they have business with me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: to them without. I am coming. The door shall be opened.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: follows and lays hold of him. Oh, for heaven's sake, have pity on me—they are merciless creditors—I shall be dragged to a prison. Do not deliver me up—I am unfortunate—I am overwhelmed with misfortune—have compassion on me!She falls on her knees.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: in great agitation. Don't kneel to me!—I don't mean you to kneel to me!—What makes you think of kneeling to me? I must do my duty. He unlocks the door.

div3.stage: Enter Nabson—Miss Dorrillon steal behind the book-case.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What did you want, Sir?

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: A lady, that I have just this minute made my prisoner; but she ran from me, and locked herself in here.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: with surprise Arrested a lady!

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and if you mean to deny her being here, I must make bold to search the room.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let me look at your credentials.— takes the writ.—"Elizabeth Dorrillon for six hundred pounds." Pray, Sir, is it customary to have female names on pieces of paper of this denomination?

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: Oh yes, Sir, very customary. There are as many ladies who will run into tradesmen's books, as there are gentlemen; and when one goes to take the ladies, they are a thousand times more slippery to catch than the men.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Abominable?—Well Sir, your present prisoner shall not slip through your hands, if I can prevent it. I scorn to defend a worthless woman, as much as I should glory in preserving a good one: and I give myself joy in being the instrument of your executing justice.— He goes and leads Miss Dorrillon from the place where she was concealed—she casts down her head.—What! do you droop? Do you tremble? You, who at the ball to-night would have danced lightly, though your poor creditor had been perishing with want! You, who never asked yourself if your extravagance might not send an industrious father of a family to prison, can you feel on the prospect of going thither yourself?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: For what cause am I the object of your perpetual persecution?

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: Lor! Madam, the gentleman means to bail you after all: I can see it by his looks.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How, rascal, dare you suppose, of imagine, or hint, such a thing?going up to him in anger.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor
sp.p: That's right, beat him out of the house.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
No, Madam, he shall not go out of the house without taking you along with him. Punishment may effect in your disposition what indulgence has no hope of producing.—There is your prisoner handing her over to him—and you may take my word, that she will not be released by me, or by any
one: and it will be only adding to a debt she can never pay, to take her to any place previous to a prison. with emotion of resentment, yet deep sorrow.

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: Is that true, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: after a pause. Very true, I have but one friend—but one relation in the world—and he is far away. weeps.Sir William wipes his eyes.

sp.speaker: Nab.
sp.p: More's the pity.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: No, Sir, no—no pity at all—for if fewer fine ladies had friends, we should have fewer examples of profligacy. She walks to the door, then turns to Sir William.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: I forgive you. Exit with Nabson.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: looking after her. And perhaps I could forgive you. But I must not. No, this is justice—this is doing my duty——this is strength of mind—this is fortitude—fortitude. He walks proudly, then throws his head into his handkerchief, going off.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Mr. Mandred, Mr. Mandred. He turns. Sir—Mr. Mandred—Sir,— in a supplicating tone I presume—I presume, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What, Madam? what?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I came, to request a favour of you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: So it should seem by that novel deportment.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: If you would for once consider with lenity, the frailty incidental to a woman who lives in the gay world—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Well, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: —How much she is led away by the temptation of fine cloaths, fine coaches, and fine things.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Come, to the business.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: You are rich we all know, though you endeavour to disguise the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I can't stay to hear you, if you don't proceed.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p:
My request is—save from the dreadful horrors of a jail, a woman who has no friend near her
—a woman who may have inadvertently offended you, but who never—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain for you to plead on her account—she knows my sentiments upon her conduct—she knows the opinion I have formed of her; and you cannot prevail on me to change it.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Do you suppose I come to plead for Miss Dorrillon?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: No, I am pleading for myself. I am unfortunately involved in similar circumstances—I have a similar debt to the self-same tradesman, and we are both at present in the self-same predicament.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And upon what pretence did you suppose I would be indulgent to you, move than to her?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Because you have always treated me with less severity; and because I overheard you just now say, you should glory in delivering from difficulty a good woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And so I should.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: How unlike the world!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: No whatever the discontented may please to say, the world is affectionate, is generous, to the good; more especially to the good of the female sex; for it is only an exception to a general rule, when a good woman is in pecuniary distress.

div3.stage: Enter Lord Priory humming a tune, but with a very serious face: he pulls out his watch with evident marks of anxiety—coughs—rubs his forehead—and gives various other marks of discontent and agitation.
Lady Mary observes him with attention, then sidles up to him.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: By the good humour you appear in, my Lord, I venture to mention to you my distresses. I know the virtues of Lady Priory make my failings conspicuous; but then consider the different modes to which we have been habituated—she excluded from temptation—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: No—she shuns temptation. Has she not in this very house been compelled to make exertions? Has she not detected and exposed both Mr. Mandred and Mr. Bronzely?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Bronzely! Bronzely! How! Aside. Another rival?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: She has not done with him yet, I believe; for, to tell the truth, he is now with her at my house in Park-street. He taxed me with being jealous of my wife—to prove in what contempt I held the accusation, I left them together, and bid him make love to her.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Is that possible?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I can't say I would have done so rash an action, had I been married to some women—to you, for instance—but I have not a doubt of Lady Priory's safety: her mind, I know, is secure; and I have servants in the house to protect her from personal outrage. The only fear is, lest he should have received one; for it is now near two hours looking at his watch. since I came away, and I have neither seen nor heard any thing of either of them!—But to your Ladyship's concerns.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I am this instant, my Lord, in the power of an implacable creditor; and without a friend who will give bond for a certain sum, I must—I blush to name it—be taken to a prison.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I am not at all surprised at the circumstance, Madam; but it amazes me that you should apply to me for deliverance. You have a brother in town; why not send to him?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: He was my friend the very last time a distress of this kind besell me. weeps.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Ask Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: He was my friend the time before.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely, then.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: And Bronzely the time before that.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Ah, Oliver! I am glad to see you, my good fellow. Hah! what have you done with Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, that I can't tell. I can't tell what he has done with himself.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How long has he been gone from my house?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: He is not gone yet as I know of; for none of the servants let him out.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Not gone! and you can't tell where he is!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: No, that we can't: we have looked in every room for him, and can't find him any where.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Not find him! recollecting himself. Ho! ho! I thought how it would be—I thought he'd have some trick played him. Where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: That I can't tell neither. We have looked in every room, and can't find her.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: 'Tis as sure as I am alive. I and the butler, two footmen, and all the maids, have been looking in parlours, chambers and garrets, every crick and corner, and no where can we find either Mr. Bronzely or my Lady; but, wherever they are, there's no doubt but they are together. Ha, ha, ha, ha ha!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! No doubt at all. Mr. Oliver.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Together! together! and not in my house! You tell a falsehood. I'll go myself and find them.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: You must look sharp, then.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How came you to miss them?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I chanced to go into the next room, to see if there was a proper fire to get it well aired; I know I had taken Mr. Bronzely to my Lady in the inner room, and I had heard them both laughing not a quarter of an hour before; but now, all on a sudden, there was neither laughing nor talking, nor any noise at all—every thing was so quiet, you might have heard a pin drop.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: anxiously. Well!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
And so I thought to myself, thought I, I'll sit down here; for my Lady will be ringing soon: however, there was no ringing for a whole half-hour,
and so then I thought I would e'en rap at the door; but nobody called "Come in." So then I went in of my own accord; and there I found—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Nobody! not a soul to be seen!

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Oh! she has been playing Bronzely some trick! She has been hiding him; and in some miserable place!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: But why need she hide herself along with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: My dear friend, my dear Lord Priory, let me speak with you alone.—I come upon business that—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: You look pale! What is your business? Tell it me at once.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: It is of so delicate a nature—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I know my wife is with Mr. Bronzely, I left them together. I know he is a licentious man; but I know she is an innocent woman.—Now, what have you to tell me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: What I have just learned from one of your servants. About a quarter of an hour after you left them, they stole softly out at the back of your house, ran to a post-chaise and four that was in waiting, and drove off together full speed.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Gone! eloped! run away from me! left me! left the tenderest, kindest, and most indulgent husband, that ever woman had!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: That we can all witness.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I was too fond of her—my affection ruined her—women are ungrateful—I did not exert a husband's authority—I was not strict enough—I humoured and spoiled her!—Bless me! what a thick mist is coming over my eyes!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: No, my Lord, it is clearing away.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Lead me to my room. He is led off by Mr Norberry, exhausted with grief and anger.

div3.stage: Oliver looks after Lord Priory, then takes out his handkerchief, and fellows him off, crying.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Oh, how I enjoy this distress! Ha, ha, ha!

stage.hi: The officer who has attended her during the scene, and kept at the farther part of the stage, now comes forward, and bows to her. She starts on seeing him—takes out her handkerchief, and goes Crying off at the opposite side.

sp.speaker: Housekeeper.
sp.p: DINNER enough for twelve, and only two to sit down to it! Come home without one preparation—not a bed aired or the furniture uncovered.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: This is not the first time he has done so.

sp.speaker: House.
sp.p: No: but 'tis always thus when a woman's in the case. Well, I do say that my own sex are—

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Hush! here they are. Run away. Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Lady Priory and Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Only twelve miles from London?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: No more, be assured.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: And you avow that I did not come hither by the commands of my husband, but was deceived into that belief by you.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Still it was by his commands your servant introduced me to you; and, upon an errand, which I feared to deliver till I arrived at a house of my own.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: What is the errand?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: To tell you that—I love you.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Do you assert, Lord Priory sent you to me for this?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I assert, that, in triumph at your betraying to him our private appointment, he gave me leave to have a second trial. If, then, you have ever harboured one wish to revenge, and forsake a churlish ungrateful partner, never return to him more—but remain with me.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: And what shall I have gained by the exchange, when you become churlish, when you become ungrateful? My children's shame! the world's contempt! and yours! Smiling Come, come; you are but jesting, Mr. Bronzely! You would not affront my little share of common sense by making the serious offer of so bad a bargain▪ Come, own the jest, and take me home immediately.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Is it impossible for me to excite your tenderness?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Utterly impossible.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I will then rouse your terror.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Even that I defy.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Lady Priory, you are in a lonely house of mine, where I am sole master, and all the servants slaves to my will.

div3.stage: Lady Priory calmly takes out her knitting, draws a chair, and sits down to knit a pair of stockings.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: aside. This composure is worse than reproach—a woman who meant to yield would be outrageous.— Goes to speak to her, then turns away—By heaven she looks so respectable in that employment, I am afraid to insult her. After a struggle with himself Ah! don't you fear me?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: No—for your fears will protect me—I have no occasion for my own.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: What have I to fear?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: You fear to lounge no more at routs, at balls, at operas, in Bond-street; no more to dance in circles, chat in side boxes, or roar at taverns: for you have observed enough upon the events of life to know—that an atrocious offence like violence to a woman, never escapes condign punishment.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Oh! for once, let your mind be feminine as your person—hear the vows—— he seizes her hand—she rises——he starts back.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Ah! did not I tell you, you were afraid? 'Tis you who are afraid of me. He looks abashed. Come, you are ashamed, too—I see you are, and I pardon you.—In requital, suffer me to return home immediately. He shakes his head.—How! are not you ashamed of yourself?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: I was not this moment—But now you mention it, I think I am.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Repent your folly then, and take me home. hastily.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Can you wish to go back to the man who has made this trial of your fidelity, and not resent his conduct?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Most assuredly I wish to return. But if you deliver me safe, perfectly safe from farther insult, it will be impossible for me not to shew resentment to Lord Priory.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Why only in that case?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Because only in that case, you will make an impression on my heart—and I will resent his having exposed me to such a temptation.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Oh! Ill take you home directly——this moment.—I make an impression on your heart. William!— calling—I'll take you home directly. Here, John, Thomas, William— calling. But, upon my life, it will be a hard task—I cannot do it—I am afraid—I cannot—Besides what are we to say when we go back?—No matter what, so you will but think kindly of me. Enter Servant.—Order the horses to be put to the chaise; I am going back to London immediately. Quick! quick! Bid the man not be a moment, for fear I should change my mind.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The chaise is ready now, Sir; for the post-boy was going back without unharnessing his horses.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then tell him he must perform his journey in half an hour—If he is a moment longer, my resolution will stop on the road. Exit Servant. I feel my good designs stealing away already—now they are flying rapidly. Take Lady Priory's hand—Please to look another way—I shall certainly recant if I see you. Going.—And now should I have the resolution to take you straight to your husband, you will have made a more contemptrible figure of me by this last trick, than by any one you have played me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: without Tell the post-boy he need not wait—I have changed my mind—I sha'n't go to London to-night.

div3.stage: Enter Miss Dorrillon and Mr. Norberry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: You ought to have known it was in vain to send for me. Have not I repeatedly declared, that, till I heard from your father, you should receive nothing more from me than a bare subsistence? I promise to allow you thus much, even in this miserable place: but do not indulge a hope that I can release you from it. She weeps—he goes to the door—then returns. I forgot to mention, that Mr. Mandred goes on board to-morrow for India; and, little as you may think of his sensibility, he seems concerned at the thought of quitting England without just bidding you farewell. He came with me hither,—shall I send him up?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Oh! no: for heaven's sake! Deliver me from his asperity, as you would save me from distraction.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis for the last time—you had better see him. You may be sorry, perhaps, you did not, when he is gone.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: No, no: I shan't be sorry.—Go, and excuse me—Go, and prevent his coming. I cannot see him. Exit Mr. Norberry This would be aggravation of punishment, to shut me in a prison, and yet not shelter me from the insults of the world!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: —I know you have desired not to be troubled with my visit; and I come with all humility—I do not come, be assured, to reproach you.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Unexpected mercy!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: No; though I have watched your course with anger, yet I do not behold its end with triumph.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: It is not to your honour, that you think it necessary to give this statement of your mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p:
May be—but I never boasted of perfection, though I can boast of grief that I am so far beneath it. I can boast too, that though I frequently give offence to others, I could never part
with any one for ever (as I now shall with you,) without endeavouring to make some atonement.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: You acknowledge, then, your cruelty to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I acknowledge I have taken upon me to advise, beyond the liberty allowed by custom to one who has no apparent interest or authority.—But, not to repeat what has passed, I come, with the approbation of your friend Mr. Norberry, to make a proposal to you for the future. he draws chairs, and they sit.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: What proposal?—What is it?eagerly.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Mr. Norberry will not give either his money or his word to release you—But as I am rich—have lost my only child—and wish to do some good with my fortune, I will instantly lay down the money of which you are in want, upon certain conditions.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Do I hear right? Is it possible I can find a friend in you?—a friend to relieve me from the depth of misery! Oh Mr. Mandred!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Before you return thanks, hear the conditions on which I make the offer.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Any conditions—What you please!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You must promise, never, never to return to your former follies and extravagancies. She looks down. Do you hesitate? Do you refuse?—Won't you promise?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: I would, willingly—but for one reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And what is that?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: The fear, I should not keep my word.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You will, if your fear be real.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: It is real—It is even so great, that I have no hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You refuse my offer then, and dismiss me?Rises.

sp.speaker: Miss. Dor.
sp.p:
rising also. With much reluctance.—But I cannot, indeed I cannot make a promise, unless I were to feel my heart wholly subdued; and my mind entirely convinced that I should never break it.—Sir, I am most sincerely obliged to you for the
good which I am sure you designed me; but do not tempt me with the proposal again—do not place me in a situation, that might add to all my other afflictions, the remorse of having deceived you.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: after a pause. Well, I will dispense with this condition—but there is another I must substitute in its stead.—Resolve to pass the remainder of your life, some few ensuing years at least, in the country. She starts. Do you start at that?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: I do not love the country. I am always miserable while I am from London. Besides, there are no follies or extravagancies in the country.—Dear Sir, this is giving me up the first condition, and then forcing me to keep it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: There, Madam, taking out his pocketbook I scorn to hold out hopes, and then destroy them. There is a thousand pounds free of all conditions she takes it—extricate yourself from this situation, and be your own mistress to return to it when you please. Going.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Oh, my benefactor, bid me farewell at parting—do not leave me in anger.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How! will you dictate terms to me, while you reject all mine?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Then only suffer me to express my gratitude—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will not heat you. going.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Then hear me on another subject: a subject of much importance—indeed it is.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: You are going to India immediately—It is possible that there, or at some place you will stop at on your way, you may meet with my father.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: You have heard that I have expected him home for some time past, and that I still live in hopes—

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Well!— anxiously.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: If you should see him, and should be in his company—don't mention me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Not mention you?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: At least, not my indiscretions—Oh! I should die, if I thought he would ever know of them.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Do you think he would not discover them himself, should he ever see you?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: But he would not discover them all at once—I should be on my guard when he first came—My ill habits would steal on him progressively, and not be half so shocking, as if you were to vociferate them all in a breath.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: To put you out of apprehension at once—your father is not coming home—nor will he ever return to his own country.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: starting. You seem to speak from certain knowledge—Oh! heavens! is he not living?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Yes, living—but under severe affliction—fortune has changed, and all his hopes are blasted.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: "Fortune changed!"—In poverty?—my father in poverty?— weeping.—Oh, Sir, excuse, what may perhaps appear an ill compliment to your bounty; but to me, the greatest reverence I can pay to it.—You are going to that part of the world where he is; take this precious gift back, search out my father, and let him be the object of your beneficence.— Forces it into his hand.—I shall be happy in this prison, indeed I shall, so I can but give a momentary relief to my dear, dear father.— Sir William takes out his handkerchief.—You weep!—This present, perhaps, would be but poor alleviation of his sufferings—perhaps he is in sickness; or a prisoner! Oh! if he is, release me instantly, and take me with you to the place of his confinement.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What! quit the joys of London?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: On such an errand, I would quit them all without a sigh—And here I make a solemn promise to you— kneeling.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Hold, you may wish to break it.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p:
Never—exact what vow you will on this occasion, I will make, and keep it.— Enter Mr. Norberry.—She rises.—Oh! Mr. Norberry,
he has been telling me such things of my father—

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Has he? Then kneel again—call him by that name—and implore him not to disown you for his child.

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Good heaven!—I dare not—I dare not do as you require. She faints on Norberry.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: going to her. My daughter! my child!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: At those names she revives.— She raises her head, in great agitation.—Come, let us quit this wretched place—she will be better then. My carriage is at the door. You will follow us.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Follow you!—Yes, and I perceive that, in spite of philosophy, justice or resolution, I could follow you all the world over. Exit.

div3.stage: Lady Mary discovered sitting in a dejected posture, at a miserable table.

sp.speaker: Lady M,
sp.p: Provoking! not an answer to one of my pathetic letters!—nor a creature to come and condole with me!—Oh that I could but regain my liberty before my disgrace is announced in the public prints—I could then boldly contradict every paragraph that asserted it—by We have authority to say, no such event took place.

div3.stage: Enter a Man belonging to the prison.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: One Sir George Evelyn is here, Madam; he will not name your name, because it sha'n't be made public; but he desires you will permit him to come and speak a few words to you, provided you are the young lady from Grosvenor-street, with whom he has the pleasure of being acquainted.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p:
Yes, yes, I am the young lady from Grosvenor-street—my compliments to Sir George, I am that lady; intimately acquainted with him; and entreat he will walk up. Exit the man. This is a most fortunate incident in my tragedy! Sir George no doubt takes me for Miss Dorrillon; yet I am sure
he is too much the man of gallantry and good breeding to leave me in this place, although he visits me by mistake.

div3.stage: Sir George Evelyn speaking as he enters.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Madam, you are free—the doors of the prison are open—my word is passed for the— He stops in surprise.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: curtsying. Sir George, I am under the most infinite obligation! Words are too poor to convey the sense I have of this act of friendship—but I trust my gratitude will for ever—

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: confused. Madam—really—I ought to apologise for the liberty I have taken.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: No liberty at all, Sir George—at least no apology is necessary—I insist on hearing no excuses. A virtuous action requires no preface, no prologue, no ceremony—and surely, if one action be more noble and generous than another, it must be that one, where an act of benevolence is conferred, and the object, an object of total indifference to the liberal benefactor.—Generous man, good evening. Call me a coach. going.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Stay, Madam—I beg leave to say—

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: —Not a word—I won't hear a word—my thanks shall drown whatever you have to say.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, did not you tell me, you had a very young lady under your care?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, so I had—but she, it seems, has just been released,, and is gone away with the gentleman who paid the debt.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Do you mean Miss Dorrillon?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I mean the other lady from Grosvenor street.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Who can have released her?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Some friend of mine, I dare say, by mistake—Well, if it is so, she is extremely welcome to the good fortune which was designed for me. For my part, I could not submit to an obligation from every one—scarcely from any one—and from no one with so little regret as I submit to it from Sir George Evelyn. Exit, curtsying.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Distraction! the first disappointment is nothing to this second! to the reflection that Miss Dorrillon has been set at liberty by any man on earth except myself. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: What a situation is mine! I cannot bear solitude, and am ashamed to see company! I cannot bear to think on the ungrateful woman, and yet I can think of nothing else! It was her conduct which I imagined had alone charmed me; but I perceive her power over my heart, though that conduct is changed!

div3.stage: Enter Mr. Norberry, Sir William, and Miss Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: My dear Lord Priory, exert your spirits to receive and congratulate a friend of mine. Sir William Dorrillon presenting him father to this young woman, whose failings he has endeavoured to correct under the borrowed name of Mandred.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And with that fictitious name, I hope to disemburthen myself of the imputation of having ever offered an affront to my Lord Priory. He takes Lord Priory aside, and they talk together.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Is it possible what I have heard is true? was it Mr. Mandred who has restored Miss Dorrillon to the protection of Mr. Norberry?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: coming forward. No, Sir George, I have now taken her under my own protection.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: By what title, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: A very tender one—don't be alarmed—I am her father.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Sir William Dorrillon?They talk apart.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p:
Has there been any intelligence of my Lady Priory yet? sees Miss Dorrillon. My dear
Dorrillon, a lover of yours has done the civilest thing by me!—As I live, here he is. How do you do, Sir George? I suppose you have all heard the news of Bronzely running away with—

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Hush!—Lord Priory is here.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Oh, he knows it—and it is not improper to remind him of it—it will teach him humility.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I am humble, Lady Mary, and own I have had a better opinion of your sex than I ought to have had.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: You mean, of your management of us; of your instructions, restrictions, and corrections.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Lady Priory and Mr. Bronzely.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: What of them?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They are here.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I said she'd preserve her fidelity! Did not I always say so? Have I wavered once? Did I not always tell you all that she was only making game of Bronzely? Did I not tell you all so?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Then, indeed, my Lord, you said truly; for I return the arrantest blockhead—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I always said you would! But how is it? Where have you been? What occasion for a post-chaise? Instantly explain, or I shall forfeit that dignity of a husband to which, in those degenerate times, I have almost an exclusive right.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: To reinstate you, my Lord, in those honours, I accompany Lady Priory; and beg public pardon for the opinion I once publicly professed, of your want of influence over her affections.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Do you hear? Do you all hear? Lady Mary, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p:
Taking advantage of your permission to call on her, by stratagem I induced her to quit your house, lest restraint might there act as my enemy.—But your authority, your prerogative, your honour
attached to her under my roof. She has held those rights sacred, and compelled even me to revere them.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Do you all hear? I was sure it would turn out so!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: This is the first time I ever knew the gallant's word taken for a woman's honour.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I will take her own word—the tongue which for eleven years has never in the slightest instance deceived me, I will believe upon all occasions. My dear wife, boldly pronounce before this company that you return to me with the same affection and respect, and the self-same contempt for this man— to Bronzely—you ever had. A short pause.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: She makes no answer.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Hush! Hush! She is going to speak.— Another pause.—Why, why don't you speak?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Because I am at a loss what to say.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Hear, hear, hear—do you all hear?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Can you be at a loss to declare you hate Mr. Bronzely?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I do not hate him.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: I was sure it would turn out so.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Can you be at a loss to say you love me?

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: She is at at a loss.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: How! Don't you fear me?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: She speaks plainly to that question.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: You know I love truth—speak plainly to all their curiosity requires.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Since you command it then, my Lord—I confess that Mr, Bronzely's conduct towards me has caused a kind of sentiment in my heart——

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Hah! What!

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: You must believe her—"she has told you truth for eleven years."

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: A sensation which—

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Stop—any truth but this I could have borne.—Reflect on what you are saying—Consider what you are doing—Are these your primitive manners?

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: I should have continued those manners, had I known none but primitive men. But to preserve ancient austerity, while by my husband's consent, I am assailed by modern gallantry, would be the task of a Stoic, and not of his female slave.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Do you hear? Do you all hear? My Lord, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: I do—I do—and though the sound distracts me, I cannot doubt her word.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: It gives me excessive joy to hear you say so, because you will not then doubt me when I add that gratitude, for his restoring me so soon to you, is the only sentiment he has inspired.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: Then my management of a wise is right after all!

sp.speaker: Mr. Nor.
sp.p: Mr. Bronzely, as your present behaviour has in great measure atoned for your former actions, I will introduce to your acquaintance my friend Sir William Dorrillon.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: Mandred, Sir William Dorrillon!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: And considering, Sir, that upon one or two occasions I have been honoured with your confidence—you will not be surprised, if the first command I lay upon my daughter, is—to take refuge from your pursuits, in the protection of Sir George Evelyn.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: And may I hope, Maria?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: No—I will instantly put an end to all your hopes.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: By raising you to the summit of your wishes, Alarmed at my severity, she has owned her readiness to become the subject of a milder government.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: She shall never repine at the election she has made.

sp.speaker: Lord Pri.
sp.p: But, Sir George, if you are a prudent man, you will fix your eyes on my little domestic state, and guard against a rebellion.

sp.speaker: Lady Pri.
sp.p: Not the rigour of its laws has ever induced me to wish them abolished.

sp.speaker: Bron.
sp.p: to Lady Pri. Dear Lady, you have made me think with reverence on the matrimonial compact—and I demand of you, Lady Mary—if, in consequence of former overtures, I should establish a legal authority over you, and become your chief magistrate—would you submit to the same controul to which Lady Priory submits.

sp.speaker: Lady M.
sp.p: Any controul, rather than have no chief magistrate at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: to Miss Dor. And what do you say to this?

sp.speaker: Miss Dor.
sp.p: Simply one sentence—A maid of the present day shall become a wife like those—of former times.

div1.head: ADDRESS,
div1.l: WELL, female critics, what's the sentence, say—
Can you with kindness treat this saucy play,
That gives to ancient dames the wreath of praise
And boldly censures those of modern days?
Bring up good husbands first, and, on my life,
For every one we'll shew as good a wife.
Whate'er the errors in the nuptial state,
Man sets th' example to his passive mate;
While all the virtues the proud sex can claim
From female influence caught the gen'rous flame.
Nay, though our gallant rulers of the main
With force resistless crush the pride of Spain
With tenfold vigour nerves the hero's arm:
For King and Country though they nobly bleed,
The smile of Beauty is their dearest meed,
And valiant tars should still be Beauty's care
